awd_titl_txt: NNA Planning: Collaborative Research: Electric Vehicles in the Arctic (EVITA) - Interactions with Cold Weather, Microgrids, People, and Policy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) is one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. NNA projects address convergence scientific challenges in the rapidly changing Arctic. The Arctic research is needed to inform the economy, security and resilience of the Nation, the larger region and the globe. NNA empowers new research partnerships from local to international scales, diversifies the next generation of Arctic researchers, enhances efforts in formal and informal education, and integrates the co-production of knowledge where appropriate. This award fulfills part of that aim by supporting planning activities with clear potential to develop novel, leading edge research ideas and approaches to address NNA goals. It integrates aspects of the natural environment, built environment, and/or social systems, and addresses important societal challenges and engages with local and Indigenous communities.

Electric vehicles (EVs) are a growing mode of transportation across the globe, and the Arctic is seeing increased interest in EV adoption. However, several fundamental gaps in knowledge must be filled to evaluate where, how, and for whom EVs can provide widespread benefits, and what might need to change to realize these benefits. For example, little data exist on the performance of EVs in cold Arctic temperatures and how EVs affect isolated rural power systems. It is also not clear how electric rates and public policies will affect EV adoption and use. This planning project brings together researchers and community members from three Alaska communities to identify perceived barriers to adoption, mechanisms for facilitating adoption, perceived usefulness, and use of EVs among different potential user groups (i.e., subsistence users, youth, elders, etc.). It also examines potential trade-offs between conventional and electric vehicles for rural users across specific use cases, such as subsistence activities. This planning project serves as the foundation for future research on EV adoption by addressing the identified knowledge gaps that can provide data and information necessary to achieve just, equitable, and sustainable energy systems in rural Arctic communities.

The focus of this planning project is on strengthening community connections by conducting planning activities for convergent engineering and social science research in partnership with three representative remote islanded grid communities (Kotzebue, Galena, and Bethel, Alaska). An initial community meeting in these three communities initiates an open discussion about visions and concerns for EVs in their community. Two more follow-up community meetings in each of the three communities continue to build collaborations and ideas. These meetings facilitate the sharing of knowledge to guide the development of interview questions and discrete choice experiments planned for future co-produced research, to seek design feedback around tools for the community to use in EV decision-making, and to strengthen connections with the communities. During these community meetings, research focuses on limited data collection on vehicle usage. Additional remote meetings of research and community project partners solidify how the knowledge sharing informs research design to address gaps in knowledge around cold weather impacts, grid impacts, and policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The EVITA planning project focused on strengthening community connections and conducting planning activities for convergent engineering and social science research in partnership with three representative remote islanded grid communities (Kotzebue, Galena, and Bethel, Alaska).  This will serve as the foundation for future research on EV adoption addressing the identified knowledge gaps that can assist underserved Indigenous communities in rural Alaska in having the data and information necessary to achieve just, equitable, and sustainable energy systems of their own. A video the highlights the partnerships forged in this project can be found on YouTube at: https://youtu.be/zHCoOhgRwCc

 

This work is unique in its engagement with remote communities in rural Alaska and the Arctic to define the likely barriers and opportunities for electric vehicles in these places.  Vehicle preferences and use cases are being combined with new data on energy use in extreme cold to model likely energy use, cost and emission implications for switching to electric vehicles, which will allow the researchers and communities to investigate best practices for transitioning this infrastructure. The knowledge we have generated can help inform how technology needs to evolve in order for a smoother adoption of electric vehicles in rural Alaska.  It can also suggest what institutional and policy changes need to be investigated, analyzed, or piloted by applied social science and policy analysis disciplines. An online calculator was developed with the help of community members (tinyurl.com/AKEVCalc), and is a new tool tailored to help Alaskan individuals and fleets make decisions about switching to EVs.

 

Kotzebue Electric Association, a project community partner, has plans to add an electric pickup truck and snow machine to their fleet. A private citizen in Galena has brought an electric car to town since the project began.  The school district in Galena is potentially interested in electric school buses.  Not all of this is directly attributable to this project, but outreach from this project is connecting people interested in EVs with information and the direct experience of others in the state. 

 

One of the most surprising and significant impacts of this planning project was the discovery of local ability to maintain an electric vehicle as one of the most highly ranked barriers to EV adoption in our partner communities, which has led to including EV maintenance curriculum development and evaluation as a workforce development component of follow on research activities.

 

Funding to community partners through this project is developing community capacity to engage with researchers, including allowing local tribes to develop staff capacity to engage in research on local energy transitions. University of Alaska researchers and community members are forming relationships that will lead to better and more responsive research better aligning the efforts of the university with the needs of Alaskans. Community residents and leaders are actively involved in envisioning and shaping a future energy system with lower fuel costs and cleaner air. Local and traditional knowledge is starting to shape the future of beneficial electrification in high-cost remote Arctic Communities. 


Last Modified: 02/27/2024
Modified by: Michelle M Wilber
